history.content:
126 also has "CS elements" in it through the labs (in Python), which IMO, are much better and useful than 140's (which are basically spoon-fed using the abstraction/naivety of the data science library). 140 is not necessarily modern. just because it is new. 126 deals with more practical applications in EECS.

Pretty much the only con of taking 126 over 140 is that the class is much more intense and challenging, has more materials and takes almost double the time in your weekly schedule compared to 140 (which isn't necessarily a "con").

I don't think 126 would "hinder" you in Data 102, but rather help you a lot, as it is more catered towards ML applications than 140 (hence, it is more useful in preparation for 189 as well).

Also, I'd advise you to have a look at the class webpages and you should (hopefully) notice that 126 covers pretty much ALL of 140 and much more.. 

tl;dr 140 is a toned-down version of 126, and while it should definitely help in preparing for ML math, it is certainly not as effective as 126.

------- 

currently taking both 126 and 140. There are definitely a lot of overlaps, but I found that I learned a good amount in both of them. Although 140 has a much lighter workload, I think it covers concepts in a clearer way than 126. If you have a good understanding of probability, or good work ethics / enough time to spend on 126, I would say definitely choose 126 over 140. However, for your reference, I did very well (> 2sd above average) in the probability section of 70, but i still found 126 to be very challenging and kind of regret enrolling in 126 (It's still a great class, tho!)

126 also has "CS elements" in it through the labs (in Python), which IMO, are much better and useful than 140's (which are basically spoon-fed using the abstraction/naivety of the data science library). 140 is not necessarily modern. just because it is new. 126 deals with more practical applications in EECS.

Pretty much the only con of taking 126 over 140 is that the class is much more intense and challenging, has more materials and takes almost double the time in your weekly schedule compared to 140 (which isn't necessarily a "con").

I don't think 126 would "hinder" you in Data 102, but rather help you a lot, as it is more catered towards ML applications than 140 (hence, it is more useful in preparation for 189 as well).

Also, I'd advise you to have a look at the class webpages and you should (hopefully) notice that 126 covers pretty much ALL of 140 and much more.. 

tl;dr 140 is a toned-down version of 126, and while it should definitely help in preparing for ML math, it is certainly not as effective as 126.

children.subject: As a student currently enrolled in 126, I have to attest to the quality of the labs; we so have covered Huffman codes, Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMCs), packet encoding, and auction theory -- all of which have a basis in probability and are used in real-life applications. For example, when Google serves you ads, they sell that ad-space via a Vickrey auction where the final buyer pays the second-highest bid. Another example is when you want to find an approximation to a global optimum where the state space is quite large (say traveling salesmen), you can use stimulated annealing which relies on MCMCs.

history.content:
The student answer looks right overall.

EECS126 can lean on 70 and the maturity that induces, and take students up from there. 140 cannot do that. Everything else is a consequence of that. Students in any major that takes 70 should be taking 126 rather than 140, if their goal is to maximize their understanding. This is the consensus position of EECS and Stat faculty. 

As far as any potential new course (like DS102) goes, the safe expectation is that a stronger preparation will always help students when they encounter a new course, especially when that course is just being built. This is because a course being built typically has "bugs" that come from some very interesting topic being added and inadvertently expecting too much prior understanding/maturity on the part of the students (since faculty can easily make a mistake in understanding the level of students, especially in expecting maturity beyond what is expected). As a result, students should always take the best preparation that they can. Nobody regrets strong foundations, although people do often take them for granted when they have them.

I've been thinking about these courses and have seen a few instructor responses about these courses. Now from what I understand, EE 126 covers most of STAT 140 in the first 6-8 weeks so it is recommended to take EE 126 over STAT 140 if you've taken CS 70.

Now I'm confused,

  • Is there nothing important in STAT 140 that 126 doesn't cover? 
  • Isn't 140 the more modern course so it is more practical, and has some interactive CS (python stuff) elements to it which 126 might not have. Is this not important?
  • I see the pros of taking 126 over 140, but what are the cons of doing so?
  • Moreover, does taking 126 instead of 140 somehow hinder (or not be as helpful) me in future Data Science courses like the upcoming DATA 102? 

It would be great if Professor Sahai could answer this question.
history.subject: EE 126 vs STAT 140
